newsitem.title: CHINA: SHANGHAI T-BILL REPO RATES, SPOTS END MOSTLY DOWN.
newsitem.headline: SHANGHAI T-BILL REPO RATES, SPOTS END MOSTLY DOWN.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mostly lower on Thursday on a technical correction after sharp gains in the past two days, traders said.
The annual rate for the most actively traded seven-day contract fell slightly to 10.70 percent from 10.78 percent on Wednesday.
Total turnover on the six-contract market fell slightly to 2.16 million lots from 2.48 million lots.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.

"The repo rates saw a technical correction today," one trader said. "Although several new firms will debut on the stock markets today and tomorrow, institutions had borrowed enough money in the past two days to cover trading in the new shares."
A domestic A share firm listed on the Shanghai stock exchange on Thursday and another is to debut on Friday.
An A share company is to list shares in Shenzhen on Friday and a B share firm is to make its debut in Shanghai.
Traders said the repo rates were likely to rise slightly on Friday, gaining some support from the new issues, which would boost fund demand on the repo market.

Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mostly down on Thursday in thin volume partly due to the strong performance of the domestic A share markets, which sucked funds out of the spot market, traders said.
The most actively traded seven-year bond that matures in August 2003 was at 99.78 yuan from 99.88 yuan.
Combined volume on the eight-contract market fell to 511,925 lots from 666,663 lots.
Traders said they saw spot contracts consolidating in the short term if A share markets continued to perform strongly.
